item.title: Bank Indonesia Official Summoned as Witness in Graft Case
item.description: A Bank Indonesia deputy governor will testify this week as a witness in a graft case related to the use of corporate social responsibility funds.
item.dc:creator: Grace Sihombing, Chandra Asmara

media:content.media:description: Filianingsih Hendarta Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

item.title: Russia's Faltering Oil Flows Crimp Gains From Rally in Prices
item.description: Crude shipments fell to the lowest since April in the four weeks to June 15
item.dc:creator: Julian Lee

media:content.media:description: The oil tanker Aulis carries a cargo of Russian crude past the Danish island of Agersø on Aug. 1, 2024

item.title: Brazil’s Lula to Push Fiscal Plan Forward Despite Setbacks in Congress
item.description: Brazil’s government has no immediate plans to develop new fiscal measures amid setbacks in Congress, and will instead seek to persuade lawmakers against blocking proposed tax increases, according to two officials with knowledge of the situation.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck, Simone Iglesias

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva

item.title: RFK Jr.’s Criticism of Fluoride Is Good News for Natural Toothpaste Brands
item.description: Fluoride-free toothpaste sales are jumping as Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and other government officials openly question the safety of the mineral long hailed as a public-health miracle.
item.dc:creator: Redd Brown

item.title: Xi, Trump Take Opposite Sides on Iran-Israel
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Jenni Marsh

media:content.media:description: The destroyed home of the Khatib family following an Iranian missile attack in Tamra, Israel, on Tuesday, June 17, 2025. Iran fired several waves of drones and missiles over the last 24 hours, while Israel continued hitting Tehran, killing one more senior military official and setting the state-television complex ablaze with a strike during a live broadcast. Photographer: Kobi Wolf/Bloomberg

item.title: Ukraine’s Parliament Backs Law Allowing Multiple Citizenships
item.description: Ukraine’s lawmakers passed a law that allows Ukrainians to hold multiple citizenships as President Volodymyr Zelenskiy seeks to strengthen ties with the diaspora and fix a demographic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Olesia Safronova

media:content.media:description: Ukrainian passports.

item.title: Trump’s Shift in Tone Raises Prospect of US Intervention in Iran
item.description: An overnight meeting between US President Donald Trump and his national security team ensured tensions remain high in the Middle East, with speculation rife the US is close to joining Israel’s attacks against Iran.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Josh Wingrove, Stephanie Lai, Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: Israeli air defense systems intercept Iranian missiles over Tel Aviv early on June 18. Photographer: Menahem Kahana/Getty Images

item.title: Demand for Oil Loading Outside Persian Gulf Soars on War Risk
item.description: Middle Eastern oil that loads outside the Persian Gulf and at least one Malaysian grade are suddenly more popular with Asian buyers as the Israel-Iran conflict threatens to imperil the passage of vessels through the Strait of Hormuz.
item.dc:creator: Yongchang Chin, Serene Cheong

item.title: Pakistan Army Chief Set for Rare Meeting With US President
item.description: President Donald Trump is expected to meet Pakistan’s army chief for talks as the US considers supporting Israeli airstrikes on Iran, a country with a cooperative and complex relationship with the government in Islamabad.
item.dc:creator: Derek Wallbank, Faseeh Mangi

media:content.media:description: Asim Munir Photographer: Iranian Presidency/Anadolu Agency/Getty Images

item.title: The US Has More Copper Than China But No Way to Refine All of It
item.description: The industry will need to overcome high energy and labor costs, environmental regulations and a glut of cheap Chinese competition to make US copper smelting great again.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Lorinc, James Attwood, Yvonne Yue Li

media:content.media:description: Vessels and residual ore at the idled Asarco smelter in Hayden, Arizona.

item.title: Supreme Court Set to Leave Town With Trump Challenges Unsettled
item.description: The US Supreme Court will close out its term in the next two weeks with a trail of unfinished business, leaving in limbo the fate of many of President Donald Trump’s most sweeping uses of executive power.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr, Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators outside the US Supreme Court in Washington on May 15. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: China Lashes Out at G-7, Von der Leyen for Criticism of Policies
item.description: China has attacked the Group of Seven nations for what it called interference in its internal affairs and chastised a top European official for criticizing Beijing’s rare earth and economic policies.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger

media:content.media:description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney and Ursula von der Leyen during the G-7 summit. Photographer: Ludovic Marin/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Modi Disputes Trump’s Version of India-Pakistan Ceasefire
item.description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi disputed President Donald Trump’s claims that trade deals were used to clinch a ceasefire with Pakistan during last month’s military conflict.
item.dc:creator: Swati Gupta, Prateek Mazumdar

media:content.media:description: Narendra Modi

item.title: Israel Begins Repatriation of Citizens Stranded By Iran Strikes
item.description: Israel is repatriating tens of thousands of its citizens stranded abroad after a flare-up in fighting with Iran, deploying emergency airlifts and ferries.
item.dc:creator: Dan Williams

media:content.media:description: Evacuees from Israel arrive at the port of Larnaca, Cyprus, on June 18. Photographer: Petros Karadjias/AP Photo

item.title: Thai Cabinet Rift Over Key Post Risks Shaking Ruling Bloc
item.description: Thailand’s ruling party and its top coalition partner are clashing over a key ministerial post, as a looming cabinet shakeup by Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra threatens to shift alliances and unsettle the conservative establishment.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Anutin Charnvirakul, left, and Paetongtarn Shinawatra, in Bangkok in August 2024.

item.title: India’s Goyal to Visit UK to Discuss Trade Deal Implementation
item.description: India’s Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal will visit the United Kingdom on June 18 to discuss the progress on the implementation of the trade deal announced last month.
item.dc:creator: Swati Gupta

media:content.media:description: Piyush Goyal

item.title: A UK Wealth Exodus? Why ‘Non-Dom’ Crackdown Risks Backfiring for Reeves
item.description: The debate over the UK’s “non-dom” status has taken center stage yet again. The decision by Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves to end a two-century old tax break for wealthy foreigners has triggered the exit of many well-heeled residents from the country.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Stupples, Leonard Kehnscherper, Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: London’s financial district

item.title: Once-Mighty Hezbollah Stays Out of Iran’s War Against Israel
item.description: One of Israel’s most feared scenarios has long been that Iran would unleash an attack on it in coordination with its powerful network of proxy militias.
item.dc:creator: Dana Khraiche, Youssef Diab

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators wave flags of Hezbollah and Iran during a rally in Tehran, on June 14.

item.title: US-China Tech Fight Widens After Taiwan Blacklists Huawei
item.description: Taiwan joined a yearslong US campaign to curtail China’s technological ascent when it blacklisted the country’s AI and chipmaking champions, an unprecedented step that may signal a resurgent effort to isolate its powerful neighbor’s semiconductor sector.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins, Miaojung Lin, Yian Lee

media:content.media:description: A Huawei Technologies Co. store in Shanghai.

item.title: Trump Flexes Security Powers to Keep Global Tariff Goal Alive
item.description: The Trump administration is pressing ahead with another tariff barrage that some trade experts say is more legally sound than the president’s country-by-country duties and may end up having an equally broad effect on imports.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Leonard, Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump Photo by Ludovic MARIN/POOL/AFP/Getty Images Photographer: LUDOVIC MARIN/Getty Images

item.title: China Consumer Rush for Subsidies Overloads Stimulus Program
item.description: China is testing the limits of what its consumer stimulus can accomplish by subsidizing purchases of select goods, fueling a shopping spree that boosted retail sales growth to the strongest in more than a year but threatening to overwhelm authorities even in the richest regions.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao, Fran Wang

media:content.media:description: Customers at an electronics retail store in Beijing.

item.title: US Lawmakers’ Talks With Top Taiwan Official Risk Irking China
item.description: A group of US lawmakers held a rare publicly disclosed meeting with Taiwan’s top defense official, a discussion that risks spurring China to step up its military intimidation of the democracy.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee, Cindy Wang

item.title: Canada, India Agree to Name New Ambassadors After Expulsions
item.description: Canada and India agreed to appoint new chief diplomats in a major step toward moving past a feud that last year saw them expel each other’s officials over accusations of transnational repression and crime.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Seal, Swati Gupta

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney greets Narendra Modi before a group photo during the Group of Seven (G7) Summit at the Pomeroy Kananaskis Mountain Lodge in Kananaskis, Alberta, Canada on June 17, 2025.

item.title: Japan to Protect Trade Interests And Not Rush Deal, Ishiba Says
item.description: Japan will prioritize protecting its national interests in trade talks without rushing into a deal with the US, Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said as he wrapped up two days of meetings at the Group of Seven gathering.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami, Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: Putin Aide Shoigu Meets Kim as Pyongyang Plans More Military Aid
item.description: Kim Jong Un discussed ongoing cooperation with Moscow in talks with President Vladimir Putin’s top security aide Sergei Shoigu, North Korea’s state media said Wednesday, after reports that Pyongyang plans to send more military personnel to support Russia.
item.dc:creator: Hyonhee Shin

media:content.media:description: This photo by the North Korean government shows Sergei Shoigu, left, with Kim Jong Un in Pyongyang on June 17. Source: Korean Central News Agency/Korea News Service/AP Photo

item.title: Australian PM Says EU Trade Deal Is ‘Symbolically Important’
item.description: Expanding trade ties between Australia and the European Union would be “symbolically important” in an environment of rising protectionism, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said Wednesday, as the two sides also plan talks on a defense agreement.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Petro Seizes Colombia Labor Reform Victory, Worrying Businesses
item.description: The Colombian Senate approved one of President Gustavo Petro’s key reforms to boost workers’ benefits, creating concerns among businesses that it would raise labor costs.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina

media:content.media:description: Gustavo Petro, Colombia’s president, speaks at the Catatumbo Social Pact in Tibu, Norte de Santander department, Colombia, Thursday, March 6, 2025. Colombia will spend 2.7 trillion pesos ($657 million) to fund programs to replace illicit coca crops and finance food production, as the government seeks solutions to the security crisis in the country's Catatumbo region.

item.title: Stefanik Asks SEC to Investigate Harvard Bond Offering
item.description: Representative Elise Stefanik called on the US Securities and Exchange Commission to investigate Harvard University’s recent bond sale, alleging the school may have withheld material information from investors about its standoff with the federal government.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Beyoud, Amanda Albright, Nicola M White

media:content.media:description: Representative Elise Stefanik

item.title: Warren Slams Hegseth Decision to Slash Pentagon Weapons Testing Office
item.description: A Pentagon plan to slash staffing at its weapons testing office threatens the safety and effectiveness of every weapons program it oversees and “will cost service members’ lives and waste taxpayer dollars,” Senator Elizabeth Warren said.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio

media:content.media:description: Pete Hegseth, US secretary of defense, during a House Appropriations Subcommittee on Defense hearing on June 10.

item.title: Meloni Pushes for Gaza Ceasefire at G-7 Amid Israel-Iran Crisis
item.description: Italian Premier Giorgia Meloni sought to rally the Group of Seven leaders to support a ceasefire in Gaza, renewing the push amid an escalation of hostilities between Iran and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Donato Paolo Mancini

media:content.media:description: Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni arrives for a working session on Ukraine during the Group of Seven (G7) Summit at the Pomeroy Kananaskis Mountain Lodge in Kananaskis, Alberta, Canada on June 17, 2025. (Photo by Ludovic MARIN / AFP) (Photo by LUDOVIC MARIN/AFP via Getty Images)
